title: How Long Can Bed Bugs Live in an Empty House?

steps.title: Bed bugs can live 3 to 5 months without a host.
steps.content: Bed bugs can live 3 to 5 months without a host. There are a few factors that can impact whether or not a bed bug can survive, but at moderate temperatures and humidity levels, adult bed bugs can last over 150 days without feeding. In fact, the longest recorded time of a bed bug living without food was 400 days, but that was in a lab under optimal conditions. The average lifespan of a bed bug is 10 months to 1 year. However, during that time they will be mating and laying eggs, ensuring new generations of bugs for years to come. Keep in mind that while bed bugs only feed on blood, they don’t just target humans. Bed bugs will feed on rodents, pets, and other animals if they have to.

steps.title: Temperature
steps.content: Temperature Bed bugs can withstand a wide temperature range, but extreme cold or warm temps will kill them. In general, temperatures below 25 °F (−4 °C) and above 119 °F (48 °C) will kill bed bugs. Bed bug eggs can survive in temperatures up to 130 °F (54 °C).

steps.title: Humidity
steps.content: Humidity Bed bugs thrive in high relative humidity zones. Studies have found that adult bed bugs can live for long periods of time in 75% to 100% humidity. However, as the humidity decreases, the lifespan of adult bed bugs does, too. [1] X Research source Low humidity levels (meaning levels under 15%) can kill bed bugs in a matter of hours. Their bodies don’t perform well under dry conditions, because they need moisture to survive.

steps.title: Age
steps.content: Age Older bed bugs can survive longer without a meal than younger bed bugs can. While adult bed bugs might be able to last months, young bed bugs may only survive for a few weeks.

steps.title: Bed bugs will hide inside any furniture left in the home.
steps.content: Bed bugs will hide inside any furniture left in the home. Typically, bed bugs will congregate in areas where people sleep or rest, like beds, couches, and chairs. Even if there are no humans in the home, bed bugs will still flock to the furniture inside. Identify bed bugs by looking for soft, red excrement on mattresses and box springs. Alternatively, examine yourself or anyone in the home for itchy, red bites, especially right after you wake up.

steps.title: Bed bugs may also hide in the walls, electrical outlets, or floorboards.
steps.content: Bed bugs may also hide in the walls, electrical outlets, or floorboards. Unfortunately, simply removing furniture won’t get rid of bed bugs for good. Since these bugs are so tiny, they can easily fit inside cracks in the wall, behind electrical outlets, behind loose trim or molding, and underneath floorboards. Check for bed bugs in these areas if the home is empty or you can’t find them on any furniture. [2] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source Bed bugs are nocturnal, meaning they mostly come out at night. However, you can find bed bugs during the day by checking any nooks and crannies in the home.

steps.title: Seal your mattress and box spring inside a plastic cover.
steps.content: Seal your mattress and box spring inside a plastic cover. If there’s still a bed in the home, cover it with plastic to suffocate and kill bed bugs. Buy a plastic cover for both your mattress and your box spring, then seal the bed bugs inside. The warmth from the plastic will speed up the process, and the bed bugs will be dead in a month or two. [3] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source Once the bed bugs are dead, uncover your mattress and vacuum up any dead bugs you see.

steps.title: Clean up any clutter in your home.
steps.content: Clean up any clutter in your home. Bed bugs love to hide in cluttered areas, so pick up any garbage or clothing on your floor. Focus on the areas around your bed specifically, since bed bugs like to stay nearby wherever humans sleep. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Vacuum your home every day.
steps.content: Vacuum your home every day. Vacuuming will suck up live bed bugs and their eggs so you can dispose of them. Vacuum your home, focusing on areas like carpets, baseboards, molding, and trim. Empty the vacuum bag into the outside garbage right away to keep the bed bugs from crawling back out again.

steps.title: Steam treat your home.
steps.content: Steam treat your home. Since steam is hot, it will automatically kill bed bugs and their eggs. Buy or rent a steamer , then make multiple passes over areas where you’ve spotted signs of bed bugs. Do this daily until you don’t see bed bugs anymore. Steam is great for soft fabrics and materials that can’t be washed, like couches, carpets, and curtains.

steps.title: Wash and dry soft items on high heat.
steps.content: Wash and dry soft items on high heat. If you know the bed bugs are on any clothing, curtains, or bedding, throw them into the washer and wash them on high heat. Then, dry them in the dryer on the highest heat setting. Since bed bugs can’t handle a high temperature, the heat from your washer and dryer will kill them. [5] X Research source Have any items that can’t be washed? Bag them up in plastic bags to suffocate the bed bugs. They’ll be dead in 1 to 2 weeks.

steps.title: Contact a professional exterminator.
steps.content: Contact a professional exterminator. Getting rid of bed bugs is tough, especially when you’re doing it on your own. When you first notice bed bugs, contact a professional right away so they can come out and inspect your home.
